prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms

response.output: Genes operate in concert within context-specific networks to perform various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can modify their functional roles and, on a broader scale, impact biological processes relevant to disease [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this scenario, understanding the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across diverse cell types is crucial to discern how genes influence complex traits [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genes operate within context-specific networks to perform various functions, with gene variations potentially altering their functional roles and impacting disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. However, a gap exists in our understanding of how these genes influence complex traits across different cell types, a knowledge that is crucial for the development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous research has explored various regulatory DNA elements and the genetic effects on gene expression across tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], and the integration of functional genomics data with GWAS data has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890; @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. In this study, we aim to bridge this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms. Our results provide a comprehensive understanding of the interplay between genetic variations, gene co-expression, and their implications for disease processes and drug repurposing. This work not only answers the posed question but also propels the field of functional genomics forward by offering novel insights into the clustering of complex traits and potential therapeutic targets.

Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: The intricate interplay of genes within context-specific networks underpins various biological functions and, when disrupted, can lead to disease-relevant processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Despite significant advances in identifying regulatory DNA elements and their genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], a comprehensive understanding of how these variations mechanistically influence complex traits across different cell types remains elusive [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge gap hinders the development of improved treatments for diseases [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. In this study, we integrate functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] to elucidate the transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. Our findings not only provide a deeper understanding of the genetic underpinnings of complex traits but also highlight potential therapeutic targets for drug repurposing, thereby advancing the field of functional genomics.

response.output: The intricate interplay of genes within context-specific networks underpins various biological functions and, when disrupted, can lead to disease-relevant processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the researchâ€™s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

response.output: The functional genomics field has made significant strides in understanding how genes, operating within context-specific networks, contribute to various biological functions and disease processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. outputs.text: Genetic studies have established that genes operate within context-specific networks to perform various functions, and variations within these genes can alter their roles, thereby influencing disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Addressing this gap is crucial as it could lead to the development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. In this study, we integrate functional genomics data and Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) data to enhance the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890; @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. Our findings provide a novel perspective on the interplay between genetic variations, gene co-expression, and disease etiology, thereby advancing our understanding of therapeutic targets and drug mechanisms. This work not only fills the existing knowledge gap but also paves the way for future research in drug repurposing and the clustering of complex traits.

---
The intricate interplay of genes within context-specific networks underpins diverse biological functions and disease processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Genetic variations can alter these functional roles, influencing disease-relevant biological processes at a higher level [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. However, a comprehensive understanding of how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic grasp of expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Despite advances in identifying regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] and genetic effects on gene expression across tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], a gap remains in integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] to elucidate transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. In this study, we address this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms. Our results provide a comprehensive map of gene co-expression clusters associated with complex traits, offering potential therapeutic targets and opportunities for drug repurposing. This work not only advances our understanding of the genetic basis of complex traits but also paves the way for more targeted and effective therapeutic strategies.

outputs.text: The intricate interplay of genes within context-specific networks underpins various biological functions and, when disrupted, can lead to disease-relevant processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Despite significant advances in identifying regulatory DNA elements and their genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], a comprehensive understanding of how these variations mechanistically influence complex traits across different cell types remains elusive [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge gap hinders the development of improved treatments for diseases [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. In this study, we integrate functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] to elucidate the transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. Our findings not only provide a deeper understanding of the genetic underpinnings of complex traits but also highlight potential therapeutic targets for drug repurposing, thereby advancing the field of functional genomics.

The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. ---
Genes operate in context-specific networks to perform various functions, and alterations in these genes can modify their functional roles. These changes can, on a broader scale, impact biological processes relevant to disease. In this regard, understanding how genes affect complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension of expression regulation across diverse cell types. This understanding should subsequently lead to the development of improved treatments. Prior research has identified different regulatory DNA elements, including the genetic effects on gene expression across various tissues. The integration of functional genomics data and Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) data has enhanced the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms. When these mechanisms are dysregulated, they often result in pathology specific to tissue and cell lineage.

outputs.text: The intricate interplay of genes within context-specific networks underpins various biological functions and, when disrupted, can lead to disease-relevant processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Despite significant advances in understanding the role of regulatory DNA elements and the genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], a comprehensive mechanistic understanding of how gene expression regulation influences complex traits across cell types remains elusive [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This gap hinders the development of improved treatments for diseases [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Here, we propose a novel approach that integrates functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] to elucidate these transcriptional mechanisms. Our results reveal that dysregulation of these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. This work not only provides a deeper understanding of the genetic underpinnings of complex traits but also paves the way for the identification of novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities.

The integration of functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms. outputs.text: The intricate interplay of genes within context-specific networks is fundamental to their functional roles and, by extension, to disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. However, a comprehensive understanding of how genetic variations influence complex traits remains elusive, largely due to the challenge of deciphering gene expression regulation across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge gap hinders the development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. In this study, we address this gap by integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890], building upon previous work that identified various regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Our results reveal novel transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. This work not only advances our understanding of the genetic underpinnings of complex traits but also provides a foundation for the identification of potential therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities.

outputs.text: Genes operate in context-specific networks to perform various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can modify their functional roles and, on a broader scale, impact biological processes relevant to disease [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this scenario, understanding the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across diverse cell types is crucial to determine how genes influence complex traits [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This understanding should subsequently lead to the development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior research has identified various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including the genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. The integration of functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms. When these mechanisms are dysregulated, they often result in pathology specific to tissue and cell lineage [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

outputs.text: The functional genomics field has made significant strides in understanding how genes, operating within context-specific networks, contribute to various biological functions and disease processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. However, a critical gap remains in our mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell types and how these variations influence complex traits [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge is crucial for the development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. In this study, we aim to bridge this gap by integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890], building on previous work that has identified various regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Our results reveal novel transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. This work not only enhances our understanding of disease etiology but also provides new avenues for therapeutic targeting and drug repurposing, thereby advancing the broader field of functional genomics.

More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

print(response)
